List-

I have placed several photos in my listfolder 'Curran'. They are of 
a tsuba that I recently acquired in trade. It is in Sasano's 'Early 
Japanese Sword Guards' as tsuba #208. Sasano has attributed his 
tsuba to the 3rd generation Kanshiro.

I do not know much about distinguishing between the different 
generations of Kanshiro work, and would like to invite open 
discussion of this tsuba. I am curious whether it is an earlier or a 
later work and would like to pin it down to within 2 generations.

The tsuba is large with a slight acorn shape to it, meaning that it 
is slightly asymetric with the widest point being at the hips.
Width there is about 81mm and height is 85 mm.
   The shakudo inserts are long, nice shakudo, and asymetrically set 
with the right hand one set a few mm higher.

Thickness is about 3.75 mm at the mimi to about 4mm at the seppa-dai.
The tsuba is very precise and finished.
    Thank you in advance,

Curran
